clinical_text:
34-year-old software engineer presents with "I just can't get out of this funk; I kind of feel like I'm drifting."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports onset of symptoms approximately 3 weeks ago after a busy project cycle ended. "I feel empty most days," and "I don't even want to do the things I used to." Reports markedly decreased interest in hobbies and social activities — stopped attending weekend meetups and has not played guitar for several weeks. Reports unintentional weight loss of about 7 lb over the past 3 weeks (approximately 5% of body weight) with decreased appetite nearly every day. Partner and patient describe noticeable slowing: "she's kind of moving slower and takes longer to get ready," and observations of reduced speech and slowed grooming. Patient endorses feelings of worthlessness and excessive self-blame nearly every day, stating "I should be doing more; it's my fault things are falling apart," and was observed tearful during the interview. Symptoms began about 3 weeks ago and have been present most days since, interfering with usual routine.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES
Denies insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day.
Denies fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
Denies diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness nearly every day.
Denies recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, suicide attempt, or specific plan.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history. No prior psychiatric medications or hospitalizations.

FAMILY HISTORY
Mother reported to have longstanding low mood treated with medication in the past; father alive and well.

MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
Hypertension managed with lisinopril 10 mg daily. Alcohol: 2–3 drinks on weekends. Denies recreational drug use. Caffeine: 1–2 cups of coffee daily. TSH normal. Metabolic panel unremarkable. Toxicology negative. Medications: lisinopril 10 mg daily; OTC ibuprofen as needed.

MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: casually dressed, slightly disheveled. Behavior: cooperative, psychomotor retardation observed (slowed movements, delayed initiation of tasks). Speech: soft, decreased rate. Mood: reports feeling "sad, empty." Affect: restricted, tearful at times. Thought process: linear and goal-directed. Thought content (delusions): no delusional beliefs elicited. Perceptions (hallucinations): no hallucinations reported. Insight: partial — recognizes change but attributes it to personal failure rather than external factors.

FUNCTIONAL IMPACT
Work: decreased productivity, missed one deadline, slower coding and review. Relationships: withdrawn from partner and friends, reduced communication. Daily activities: difficulty initiating routine chores, decreased self-care and leisure activities.

1. DEMOGRAPHICS AND CHIEF COMPLAINT
28-year-old graphic designer presents with "I can't focus, I'm always restless, and I'm messing up projects" (patient's words).

2. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports a long-standing pattern of inattention and high activity beginning in childhood; symptoms first appeared around age 9. Over the past approximately 6 months symptoms have intensified with missed deadlines and more frequent workplace errors. "I start a task and then I get pulled away by everything," the patient said. Describes frequent careless mistakes (overlooks file details, produces inaccurate proofs), difficulty sustaining attention during meetings or when reading long briefs, and often appearing not to listen when colleagues speak — "my mind is somewhere else even when someone is talking to me." Reports starting tasks but losing focus, leaving multiple projects incomplete, failing to return client calls and forgetting appointments. Notes chronic disorganization (messy desk, lost keys, misplaced external drives) and poor time management leading to reprimands at work. Describes being easily distracted by noises or stray thoughts, frequent fidgeting (tapping feet/hands), feeling internally restless and "on the go," and speaking rapidly and often interrupting others. Reports blurting answers in meetings and difficulty waiting turns. Also endorses persistent excessive worry about work performance and future projects for months, difficulty controlling these worries, feeling keyed up, easy fatigue, muscle tightness, episodes of mind going blank, irritability, and restless, unrefreshing sleep. "I lie awake replaying what I did wrong," patient said.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES: Denies suicidal ideation, homicidal ideation, self-harm, hallucinations, and fixed false beliefs.

3. PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history.

4. FAMILY HISTORY
Family history notable for a parent with substance use; no known psychiatric treatment in immediate family.

5. MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
No significant medical illnesses. Alcohol: 1–2 drinks on weekends. Recreational drugs: denies use. Caffeine: 2–3 cups coffee daily. TSH normal. Metabolic panel unremarkable. Toxicology negative. Medications: none prescribed; uses OTC ibuprofen as needed.

6. MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: casually dressed, slightly disheveled. Behaviour: restless, frequent shifting in seat, taps foot. Speech: rapid, pressured at times. Mood: reports being "stressed and keyed up." Affect: congruent, somewhat irritable. Thought process: linear but tangential at times with frequent interruptions. Thought content (delusions): denies fixed false beliefs. Perceptions (hallucinations): denies hallucinations. Insight: limited recognition of severity of work impact but willing to consider strategies.

1. DEMOGRAPHICS AND CHIEF COMPLAINT
24-year-old graduate student presents with "I'm kind of all over the place and messing up my work sometimes."

2. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports a roughly 6-month period of increased difficulties with day-to-day tasks and work performance, with current problems "worse than usual." States symptoms began around age 10. Describes often overlooking details on assignments ("I miss little things, so my reports end up inaccurate") and frequently producing messy, disorganized work. Reports difficulty managing sequential tasks and time—"I start things and then lose track; deadlines sneak up on me"—and often avoids paperwork or long reviews because they feel effortful ("I kind of put off the long reports"). Gives concrete examples: repeatedly misplacing keys and phone, turning in an incomplete lab assignment, arriving late to meetings after losing papers, and forgetting to pay a bill. Notes being easily distracted by noises and by "other thoughts that pop into my head," and acknowledges frequent tapping of hands/feet when seated and a tendency to get up during lectures or meetings. Describes blurting out answers in group discussions ("I sometimes finish people's sentences") and difficulty waiting in line without impatience. Timeline: problems intermittently present since childhood, more disruptive in the past 6 months with increased missed deadlines and relationship strain. Two direct quotes: "I'm kind of embarrassed I keep losing things" and "I avoid paperwork because it's just draining."

Pertinent negatives: Denies difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play activities (e.g., remaining focused during lectures, conversations, or lengthy reading). Denies not seeming to listen when spoken to directly. Denies not following through on instructions and failing to finish schoolwork, chores, or duties in the workplace. Denies being "on the go," acting as if "driven by a motor."

3. PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history or formal mental health treatment.

4. FAMILY HISTORY
Family history notable for a father who had difficulty with organization and restlessness; no known formal psychiatric treatment in family.

5. MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
No significant medical history reported. Alcohol: social drinking 1–2 times/week. Recreational drugs: denies current illicit drug use. Caffeine: 2–3 cups coffee daily.

6. MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: casually dressed, somewhat disheveled. Behaviour: fidgety, frequently tapping foot and shifting in chair. Speech: normal volume, slightly hurried at times. Mood: reports feeling "frustrated" and "embarrassed." Affect: mildly constricted, congruent with stated mood. Thought process: generally linear but intermittently interrupted by unrelated thoughts. Thought content: no delusional ideas reported. Perceptions: denies hallucinations. Insight: fair—recognizes difficulties and attributes some to personal habits.

DEMOGRAPHICS AND CHIEF COMPLAINT
34-year-old paramedic presents with "I can't get the images out of my head."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports onset approximately 1 month ago after responding to a large apartment explosion on 2025-12-03. Describes directly experiencing the blast ("I was thrown against a wall"), witnessing multiple victims including a coworker who was burned and died at the scene, and later learning that his close friend (roommate) was killed in the same event. As a first responder he reports repeated exposure to grisly details while assisting with recovery: "I kept opening bags and identifying people, it felt endless." He endorses recurrent, involuntary memories: "They pop into my mind when I'm driving or when I close my eyes." Reports recurrent nightmares with the explosion and screams, and several dissociative episodes where he feels as if he is back at the scene, describing sensory re-experiencing and temporary loss of present surroundings. Notes marked distress and racing heart when passing the building or when hearing sirens, and an exaggerated startle when someone taps him. He avoids driving past the block, avoids talking about the event, and has difficulty recalling about 10–20 minutes immediately after the blast. Patient reports pervasive self-blame: "I should have done more to save him," and says he now believes the world is unsafe and that he cannot trust his judgment. Endorses persistent fear, shame, anger, decreased interest in hobbies, withdrawal from friends, irritability with coworkers, one episode of reckless driving since the event, hypervigilance at night, trouble concentrating at work, and difficulty falling and staying asleep.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history.

FAMILY HISTORY
Family history noncontributory; no known psychiatric diagnoses reported.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES
Denies auditory or visual hallucinations. Denies current suicidal ideation, plan, or intent. Denies homicidal ideation.

MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
No chronic medical conditions reported. Substance use: alcohol 1–2 beers on weekends, denies recreational drug use, caffeine 2–3 cups/day. TSH normal. Metabolic panel unremarkable. Toxicology negative. Medications: ibuprofen PRN, no prescriptions.

MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: disheveled, wearing work uniform. Behavior: restless, repeatedly checks phone. Mood: "on edge, numb." Affect: constricted, tearful at times, congruent with stated mood. Thought content: preoccupation with event, intrusive memories; denies suicidal/homicidal intent or active plans; protective factors include dependent children and intent to seek help. Cognition: alert and oriented x3; attention and concentration impaired on serial 7s; memory for remote events intact, recent memory with gaps regarding peri-event period. Insight: partial; recognizes symptoms but attributes them to personal failure.

DEMOGRAPHICS AND CHIEF COMPLAINT
18-year-old college student presents with "I can't follow conversations and people think I'm rude."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports a marked change over the past three weeks with increased social withdrawal and escalation of longstanding interpersonal difficulties that the patient reports began around age 16. "I run out of things to say and then just stop," and "I don't understand the faces people make; it feels like signals I can't read." Timeline: patient describes baseline difficulties with peers since age 16 but notes a recent exacerbation beginning approximately 3 weeks ago when they started avoiding study groups and missing classes. Examples: during a group project, patient reports failing to respond to classmates' questions, later repeating classmates' sentences aloud (echolalia) and lining up pens repeatedly to calm themselves. Patient describes rigid morning routine—must eat the same cereal and take the same route to campus; a small change (bus detour) produced a 45-minute meltdown. Reports intense preoccupation with train timetables and spends hours watching schedule apps, becoming agitated if interrupted. Sensory report: "Certain cafeteria noises make me cover my ears," and avoids clothing with particular textures. Notes poor eye contact, limited facial expression, and frequent hand-flapping when anxious.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history or formal treatment reported.

FAMILY HISTORY
Mother reportedly had longstanding difficulty regulating mood; no known formal psychiatric diagnoses in other relatives.

MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
No significant medical history. No current medications. Occasional caffeine. Denies tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drug use.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES
Denies hallucinations. Denies suicidal ideation or self-harm. Denies recent substance use.

MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: casually dressed, neat. Behaviour: avoids eye contact, repetitive hand movements (finger flicking) noted. Speech: low volume, literal, occasional immediate echolalia. Mood (subjective): "anxious and exhausted." Affect (observed): constricted, limited range. Thought process: concrete, perseverative on routines and timetables; no delusional content. Cognition: alert, oriented x3, attention intact though easily distracted by sensory input. Insight: limited awareness of social impact of behaviors, recognizes distress but attributes problems to others not understanding them.

29-year-old graphic designer presents with "I can't keep my mind on anything; I keep missing deadlines."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient reports ~6 months of worsening concentration and energy. "I start a project and then I'm off to something else," and "I can't sit through meetings without getting up." Timeline: symptoms began insidiously in July 2025 and have been persistent since. Patient describes frequent careless errors on client files (overlooked image layers, wrong color codes), missing deadlines on three recent projects, and handing in incomplete work after losing focus. Describes difficulty sustaining attention during lectures and long documents, mind "elsewhere" even without distractions; often does not appear to listen when colleagues speak. Reports starting tasks then quickly becoming sidetracked (e.g., begins a report, spends an hour on unrelated emails, then abandons it). Avoids paperwork and lengthy reviews, saying "I put it off until it's due and then panic." Frequently misplaces keys, phone, and paperwork; missed a scheduled dentist appointment and a client call. Reports feeling restless—tapping feet, leaving seat during meetings to pace, and feeling "driven" and uncomfortable sitting still. Talks quickly in meetings and often interrupts or blurts answers. Sleep reduced to 4–5 hours some nights with early morning awakening; appetite decreased with 6 lb weight loss in past month. Describes pervasive low mood, tearfulness, feelings of worthlessness and excessive guilt about work performance: "I feel like I'm failing everyone." Reports recurrent thoughts of death without a concrete plan; denies recent attempts. Symptoms present for approximately 6 month(s). Symptoms first appeared around age 9.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES:
Denies current suicidal plan or intent; denies history of suicide attempts. Denies visual or auditory hallucinations. No delusional ideas reported.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY:
No prior psychiatric history; no prior psychotherapy or medication trials.

FAMILY HISTORY:
Father with chronic mood difficulties; mother alive and well.

MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES:
No chronic medical conditions. Alcohol: 1–2 drinks socially per month. Recreational drugs: denies use. Caffeine: 2–3 cups coffee daily. TSH normal; metabolic panel unremarkable; toxicology negative. Medications: no prescriptions; takes OTC ibuprofen as needed.

MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION:
Appearance: casually dressed, mildly disheveled. Behaviour: restless, frequently shifts in seat. Speech: rapid, sometimes interrupts. Mood: "down, frustrated." Affect: constricted, tearful at times. Thought process: tangential at points, distractible. Thought content: passive thoughts of death; no delusions. Perceptions: denies hallucinations. Insight: limited; judgment appears impaired in planning and time management.

1. DEMOGRAPHICS AND CHIEF COMPLAINT
"34-year-old high school teacher presents with "I'm worrying all the time and can't switch my brain off."" 

2. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports approximately six months of persistent, excessive worry about work performance, classroom management, and future evaluations. Symptoms began around July 2025. Patient states, "I replay every lesson in my head and imagine every mistake," and "I can't stop thinking about what could go wrong." Worry occurs most days, often starting in the morning and worsening in evenings. Patient describes difficulty controlling the worry, reporting repeated attempts to reassure self that are unsuccessful. Endorses feeling constantly keyed up and restless, with muscle tightness in the neck and shoulders and jaw clenching. Reports being easily fatigued despite spending extra hours awake; "I can get through the day but by 3 PM I'm exhausted." Describes concentration lapses in meetings with episodes of mind going blank and forgetting students' names. Reports increased irritability—short temper with partner and coworkers—resulting in heated exchanges. Sleep is disrupted: difficulty falling asleep, waking several times, and nonrestorative sleep. Uses direct examples: double-checking emails late at night, arriving late to grade papers because of rumination, and cancelling a weekend staff event due to worry.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES (explicitly deny these):
Denies suicidal ideation. Denies homicidal ideation. Denies hearing voices or seeing things. Denies current recreational drug use. Denies recent hospitalization for psychiatric reasons.

3. PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history. No prior psychotherapy or psychotropic medications.

4. FAMILY HISTORY
Mother has longstanding excessive worry and takes an unspecified psychiatric medication.

5. MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
No major medical illnesses reported. Alcohol: 1–2 drinks on weekends. Recreational drugs: none. Caffeine: 2–3 cups coffee daily. 'TSH normal', 'metabolic panel unremarkable', 'toxicology negative'. Medications: occasional ibuprofen, melatonin PRN.

6. MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: casually dressed, slightly fatigued. Behavior: fidgety, frequently shifts in chair. Speech: fluent, slightly rapid, coherent. Mood (subjective): "tense and tired." Affect (observed): constricted, anxious-appearing. Thought process: linear but ruminative, preoccupied with future problems. Cognition: oriented to person/place/time, attention fluctuates with occasional blanking. Insight: acknowledges problem and expresses desire for help.

24-year-old graduate student presents with "I'm kind of all over the place and can't focus on anything."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient reports a roughly 6-month course of increasing difficulties with attention and activity that began about 6 months ago and first appeared around age 10. States, "I start things and don't finish them," and "I lose my phone or my keys all the time," and "I'm kind of always tapping my foot or moving." Describes frequent careless mistakes in coursework and research notes—overlooking details on data sheets and submitting inaccurate calculations. Reports difficulty sustaining attention during long lectures and readings; "my mind sort of wanders even when I want to follow along." Notes appearing not to listen when spoken to directly; says people tell them their "mind seemed elsewhere" in meetings. Describes trouble following through on tasks (starts literature reviews then moves on to other tasks), disorganized materials and missed deadlines, and frequently misplacing notebooks and glasses. Observes motor restlessness: fidgets with hands, taps feet, leaves seat in seminars, and feels "on the go" in social settings. Reports talking a lot in group meetings and sometimes interrupting peers or starting to use others' materials without asking. Symptoms reported as present daily and impairing for approximately 6 months.

Functional impact:
- Work/academic: Missed deadlines, repeated errors in lab data, decreased productivity in assistantship duties.
- Relationships: Strained peer collaborations due to interrupting and taking over tasks; friends note impatience.
- Daily activities: Misplaces keys/phone multiple times weekly, difficulty organizing bills and papers at home.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES:
Denies often avoids, dislikes, or is reluctant to engage in tasks that require sustained mental effort. Denies is often easily distracted by extraneous stimuli. Denies is often forgetful in daily activities. Denies often unable to play or engage in leisure activities quietly.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY:
No prior psychiatric history; no prior medications or psychotherapy reported.

FAMILY HISTORY:
Mother described as having longstanding difficulties with restlessness and was treated with medication for "nerves."

MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES:
No significant medical problems reported. Alcohol: 1–2 drinks socially weekly. Recreational drugs: denies regular use. Caffeine: 2–3 cups coffee daily.

MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION:
Appearance: casually dressed, slightly unkempt. Behaviour: frequently fidgeted, tapped hands/feet, shifted in chair. Speech: spontaneous, somewhat rapid, often interrupts interviewer. Mood: "a bit stressed, kind of frustrated." Affect: reactive, range present but restless. Thought process: goal-directed but frequently shifts topics and occasionally jumps between subjects. Thought content (delusions): Denies fixed false beliefs. Perceptions (hallucinations): Denies hallucinations. Insight: acknowledges problems with attention and organization but attributes much to poor time management and stress.

1. DEMOGRAPHICS AND CHIEF COMPLAINT
34-year-old paramedic presents with "I keep reliving the crash and I can't sleep" and "Everything smells like gasoline and blood when it happens again."

2. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports onset approximately 1 month ago after responding to a multi-vehicle collision on 12/02/2025 in which his ambulance was struck. He describes directly experiencing the collision ("I felt the whole rig flip, my face hit the glass"), witnessing coworkers and bystanders injured and one colleague die at the scene, and later learning that a close friend who had been in a different crash died two weeks after the event. As a first responder he reports repeated exposure to gruesome details during extrication and at the hospital. He reports recurrent, involuntary memories: "I see the metal folding over and hear her scream over and over" and recurrent nightmares in which he is back in the vehicle and trapped. He describes episodes in public where he feels transported back to the scene, drops to the floor, and perceives the same sounds and smells; during these episodes he experiences pounding heart, sweat, and shaking. Notes marked distress when exposed to ambulance sirens, the route where the crash occurred, or conversations about vehicle accidents; reports avoidance of driving that route, refusing highway shifts at work, and avoiding colleagues who were at the scene. Patient cannot recall parts of the event, specifically a 10–15 minute interval before extrication. Reports persistent feelings of guilt and that "it was my fault," pervasive fear and numbness, decreased interest in recreational running, increasing distance from spouse, irritability with loud noises, one episode of reckless speeding the week prior, hypervigilance when on duty, excessive startle to door slams, difficulty concentrating, and trouble falling and staying asleep. Duration: Symptoms present for approximately 1 month; began after 12/02/2025 event.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES
Denies current hearing voices; denies seeing things that others do not; denies current intent to harm others.

FUNCTIONAL IMPACT
Work: Avoids highway calls, called out sick 4 times in past month, decreased performance during shifts due to concentration lapses. Relationships: Reports growing distance from spouse, irritability and withdrawal from friends and coworkers. Daily activities: Stopped running, avoids driving certain routes, difficulty completing household tasks due to sleep loss and intrusive memories.

3. PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history.

4. FAMILY HISTORY
Mother alive, no known psychiatric treatment; father deceased, history of alcohol problems.

5. MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
No chronic medical conditions reported. Substance use: drinks alcohol 2–3 times per week (2–3 beers per occasion), denies recreational drugs, uses caffeine daily (2–3 coffees). Labs: TSH normal, metabolic panel unremarkable, toxicology negative. Medications: OTC ibuprofen PRN.

6. MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: casually dressed, hygiene appropriate. Behavior: cooperative but frequently looks away, at times visibly trembling. Mood: "on edge, guilty." Affect: constricted, reactive to trauma content. Thought content: intrusive memories and preoccupation with event; denies current suicidal ideation; reports fleeting passive wish "I wish it had been me" twice in past two weeks, no plan, no intent; protective factors include spouse and employment. Cognition: oriented x3, concentration impaired by intrusive recollections. Insight: recognizes symptoms relate to the event and wishes to get help.

19-year-old college student presents with "I don't know how to talk to people; I like my routines."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports long-standing difficulties beginning in mid-adolescence with a clear recent exacerbation. "I have liked lining things up since I was a kid," and "If my bus is different I get really upset." Symptoms first became noticeable around age 16 and have increased in intensity over the last three weeks. Duration: Symptoms present for approximately 3 week(s). They began as a clearer worsening of longstanding patterns that started at age 16. Patient describes limited back-and-forth in conversation: when asked about school, responds with factual monologues about train schedules rather than answering questions or asking reciprocal questions. Often does not initiate greetings and sometimes does not respond when others speak; staff report patient will sit quietly and not return a greeting. Nonverbal communication is limited—poor eye contact, minimal facial expression, rigid posture; patient describes not understanding gestures and frequently misreads tone. Repetitive behaviors include lining up pens by length, frequent hand-flapping when anxious, and repeating phrases heard on television. Reports extreme distress when routine is altered (missed bus route led to crying and leaving class early), and insists on same route to campus and same meal each day. Interests are narrow and intense (detailed knowledge of public transit schedules; spends hours collecting timetable printouts). Sensory features reported: adverse reaction to loud cafeteria noise, excessive smelling of clothing fabric for reassurance, and prolonged visual fixation on ceiling fans.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history.

FAMILY HISTORY
Mother reported to have long-standing difficulties with mood and social withdrawal; no other family mental health history reported.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES
Denies suicidal ideation. Denies self-harm. Denies auditory or visual hallucinations. Denies recent substance use.

MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
No significant medical history. No current medications.

MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: casually dressed, neat. Behavior: repetitive hand movements noted throughout interview, limited reciprocal gestures. Speech: monotone, concrete, occasionally echolalic phrases. Mood (subjective): "anxious when plans change." Affect (observed): constricted, minimal range. Thought process: concrete, perseverative, occasional tangential focus on special interests. Cognition: oriented x3, attention adequate though easily distracted by sensory stimuli. Insight: limited regarding social difficulties and impact on functioning.

FUNCTIONAL IMPACT
Work/academic: Missed classes due to rigid travel routine and sensory overwhelm; difficulty participating in group projects. Relationships: Few peer friendships, difficulty sustaining reciprocal interactions, avoids social invitations. Daily activities: Daily meal and travel routines dominate schedule; distress and functional disruption with minor changes.

DEMOGRAPHICS AND CHIEF COMPLAINT
34-year-old software engineer presents with "I kind of don't enjoy anything anymore" and "I'm having trouble getting through the day."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Symptoms began approximately 3 weeks ago after a project deadline passed. Patient reports "I just don't want to do hobbies I used to like — even gaming or cooking feels empty," and "I can't focus on work; it's like my brain is foggy." Patient describes a noticeable weight loss of about 8% over the past month attributed to eating less: "I sometimes forget to eat or only nibble." Sleep is disrupted nearly every night with initial insomnia and early morning awakening: "I lie awake for hours and sometimes nap in the afternoon but don't feel rested." Patient reports pervasive feelings of worthlessness and excessive guilt: "I feel like I'm useless and like I've let everyone down," and sometimes expresses belief that they are responsible for others' problems despite contrary evidence. Patient notes marked indecisiveness and diminished concentration affecting routine tasks.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history. No prior psychiatric medications or hospitalizations.

FAMILY HISTORY
Mother has a history of long-term treatment for mood symptoms; no other known psychiatric history.

MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
No significant medical illnesses reported. Substance use: alcohol 1–2 drinks on weekends, denies daily alcohol use; denies recreational drug use; caffeine: 2–3 cups coffee per day. Labs: TSH normal, metabolic panel unremarkable, toxicology negative. Medications: occasional OTC ibuprofen; no prescribed medications.

PERTINENT NEGATIVES
Denies depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day. Denies psychomotor agitation or retardation observed by others. Denies fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day. Denies recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, or a plan.

MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: casually dressed, slight weight loss evident. Behavior: cooperative, sits quietly. Speech: soft, slightly hesitant, normal rate. Mood: reports feeling "kind of numb" at times; denies pervasive sadness. Affect: constricted range, appropriate to content. Thought process: goal-directed but slowed by frequent pauses and indecisiveness. Thought content: expresses pervasive feelings of worthlessness and excessive guilt; holds some overgeneralized beliefs about responsibility for others' problems. Perceptions: denies hallucinations. Insight: limited; recognizes symptoms but attributes them to personal failure.

29-year-old software engineer presents with "I'm kind of worried about everything, especially work, and I can't turn it off."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports a roughly 6-month history of pervasive worry that began around July 2025. Worry occurs more days than not and focuses on multiple domains, primarily work performance and upcoming evaluations, but also occasionally social and financial situations. Patient states, "I spend hours going over what I said in meetings," and "sometimes I wake up already thinking about the day and can't stop." Reports difficulty controlling the worry: attempts to distract or problem-solve only partially helpful and worries return. Describes persistent muscle tension with tightness in the neck and shoulders and frequent jaw clenching. Endorses increased time spent double-checking code and emails, leading to longer workdays. Duration approximately 6 months.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY
No prior psychiatric history.

FAMILY HISTORY
Mother had episodes of long-standing low mood treated in the past; father has hypertension.

MEDICAL HISTORY AND SUBSTANCES
No significant medical conditions reported. Substance use: alcohol 1–2 drinks once weekly, denies recreational drug use, caffeine 2–3 cups coffee daily. Labs: TSH normal, metabolic panel unremarkable, toxicology negative. Medications: no current prescription medications; OTC ibuprofen PRN.

MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Appearance: casually dressed, slightly hunched posture with hands often on shoulders. Behavior: cooperative, engaged but somewhat tense. Speech: normal rate and volume. Mood (subjective): "a little on edge, kind of worried most days." Affect (observed): anxious, restricted range at times. Thought process: linear and goal-directed but preoccupied with future events and performance concerns. Thought content: no suicidal or homicidal ideation reported; no perceptual disturbances. Cognition: oriented to person, place, time; memory intact on bedside testing. Insight: recognizes worries are excessive and reports difficulty controlling them. Denies restlessness or feeling keyed up or on edge. Denies being easily fatigued. Denies difficulty concentrating or mind going blank. Denies irritability.

FUNCTIONAL IMPACT
Work: decreased efficiency, longer work hours, missed deadlines from repeated checking and reworking tasks. Relationships: withdraws from partners/friends when rumination is heavy, declines social invitations. Daily activities: delays household tasks, spends evening hours ruminating, reports muscle tightness interferes with comfortable sleep position.

27-year-old software engineer presents with "I can't focus at work, I start things and never finish them, and lately I feel sad all the time."

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient reports ~6 months of worsening concentration and low mood. "I miss details in code reviews and miss deadlines," and "my mind just drifts in meetings — I hear things but it's like I'm not there." Symptoms present for approximately 6 month(s); began around July 2025. Patient describes lifelong patterns of distractibility, noting "this started when I was a kid," and states, "I remember having trouble sitting still in class." Symptoms first appeared around age 9. Timeline: childhood inattentive behaviors reported, relatively managed until 6 months ago when workload increased and low mood and sleep disturbance emerged. Reports difficulty sustaining attention during lectures, long documents, and conversations; often does not seem to listen when spoken to directly (mind elsewhere). Describes frequent careless mistakes at work, losing keys and paperwork multiple times per week, and starting tasks but quickly becoming sidetracked.
